titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Richard Moore Papers
titlestmt.author: by Leigh Golden and Jennifer Meehan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday December 9, 2018 at 05:31

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection documents the literary career and creative process of the poet and author, Richard Moore, and sheds light on his personal and professional relationships and interests. Papers include writing and professional files; correspondence and subject files relating to literary figures; drafts and manuscripts of Moore's poetry and prose; and manuscripts of writings by others. Also present is an extensive journal kept by Moore from 1956 to 2007, as well as other personal and family papers.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Richard Moore Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard Moore Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, in 2010. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during basic processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Richard Moore (1927-2009)
bioghist.p: Richard Moore (Yale 1950) is the author of ten volumes of poetry; a novel, The Investigator (1991); a collection of essays, The Rule That Liberates (1994); and translations of Plautus's Captivi (1995) and Euripedes's Hippolytus (1998). Moore's books of poetry include The Mouse Whole: An Epic (1996), Pygmies and Pyramids (1998), and The Naked Scarecrow (2000). Moore taught at Boston University, Brandeis University, the New England Conservatory of Music, and Clark University. He led the Agape poetry series in Boston and The Poetry Exchange in Cambridge, Massachusetts and Leesburg, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection documents the literary career and creative process of the poet and author, Richard Moore, and sheds light on his personal and professional relationships and interests. Papers include writing and professional files; correspondence and subject files relating to literary figures; drafts and manuscripts of Moore's poetry and prose; and manuscripts of writings by others. Also present is an extensive journal kept by Moore from 1956 to 2007, and other personal and family papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Files from Office/Bedroom Filing Cabinet, 1940-2009. II. Correspondence and Subject Files, 1940-2008. III. Writings, 1943-2007. IV. Journal, 1956-2007. V. Other Papers, 1940-2007.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Files have been left in the order in which they were removed from the filing cabinets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I. consists of files removed from the filing cabinets located in the room which served as Moore's office and bedroom. Files contain drafts of writings, notes, correspondence, and other material broadly relating to Moore's literary endeavors and professional interests. File titles have been transcribed from the original folders, and the file numbering system is Moore's own, although it has yet to be determined what the letter and number sequence means.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Personal Correspondence and Literary Correspondence and Subject Files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II. consists of correspondence with family and friends, and various sets of correspondence and subject files by and about various poets, authors, and other literary figures. Files include incoming correspondence, drafts and carbons of outgoing correspondence, clippings, reading announcements, and other material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Subseries contains several different alphabetical groupings that have not been organized into a single alphabetical arrangement.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Writings are not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Writings, includes drafts of poems and prose, notes, correspondence, and other material related to Moore's various literary endeavors. Also found are drafts of writings by others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV. consists of Moore's journal, which is comprised of loose-leaf pages, written on both sides and compiled into sixteen "volumes" and three "levels." Each level was originally supported by a wooden base with strings on the top and bottom ends for maneuvering. The levels were stacked one on top of the other in a cardboard box with the first level ("L1") on the bottom and the third level ("L3") on the top; and the volumes were stacked in reverse chronological order on each level. For example, "L1" contained Volumes I to VI, with Volume I on the bottom and Volume VI on the top. For preservation and access purposes, the journal pages have been rehoused in acid-free folders. But the original dividers and cardboard box have been retained for reference and study purposes.

did.unittitle: Original box from which journal was removed

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V. includes copies of Moore's published books with his annotations, student papers, notes, and other papers.
